I agree that it looks idiotic, but the behavior that the OP is seeing is 
exactly how JUnit 3.8.1 has always worked /for assertions of 
primitives/. Look at the source of the junit.framework.Assert class. All 
of the assert*()s that compare primitives ultimately call fail(), with a 
null message argument if no message was used as the first argument to 
assert*(). This is the 'null' that you see in the test result printout. 
Is this horrible user feedback? Yes. Note that the assertions for 
Strings and Objects, instead of calling fail(), throw a 
ComparisonFailure object. This is an extension of AssertionFailedError 
that crafts an exception message string that's a bit more user-friendly 
(i.e. the infamous "expected <....> but was <...>" message).

IIRC, the junit-addons package 
(http://sourceforge.net/projects/junit-addons) has an alternative Assert 
class that prints out much nicer exception messages.

> I've never heard of such behaviour. What version of JUnit are you using?
